slidelink.displaytext: 4 - Have you ever tried a new learning activity and wonder if it was really effective?
5 - Is there an educational issue that you wish you understand better?
6 - Have you ever wondered about the potential of hidden biases to creep into the assessment of your students?
7 - The questions that drive research are all around us.
11 - A BRIEF HISTORY OF EDUCATIONAL RESEARCH
15 - THE NATURE OF SCIENTIFIC INQUIRY: PURPOSES
16 - THE NATURE OF SCIENTIFIC INQUIRY: PRINCIPLES

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript: Hello everyone! Welcome to the course on the principles of educational research. This lecture is designed by Dr. Candace Chou and narrated by Dr. Karen Kozen-Lien.

In this video, you will learn a brief history of educational research, the principles of scientific inquiry, the various types of educational research, and key components for writing a research article.

Have you found situations like in this cartoon that you are wondering about the effectiveness of a new tool in the classroom? You are hearing both positive and negative comments and might be curious about how it might work for your classroom or school?
Have you ever tried a new learning activity and wonder if it was really effective?
Is there an educational issue that you wish you understand better? For example, why is there a higher representation of minority students in the special education classroom?
Have you ever wondered about the potential of hidden biases to creep into the assessment of your students and making assumption about student learning abilities?

Look around your surrounding and you will many questions that we do not have definite answers.

After seeing the four cartoons from the previous slide on various issues in education, now pause the video for one minute to take a moment to write down one or a few questions in your classroom or school that needs answers or a bit deeper understanding.

Ok, write down a question is the first step of conducting a research. You conduct a research because you want to find out what is happening in your classroom or school or a specific education setting. Philosopher Joseph Campbell once said that “research is a blind date with the truth.” There are some implications to this statement. The idea of a blind date is that you hopefully are coming to a research seeking truth without biases, prejudices, or pre-conceived notion.

The world “Research”comes from the French word, “rechercher” meaning ”to investigate thoroughly.” The implication is to do a disciplined, systematic, and thorough job in seeking answers to your questions.

Educational research utilizes scientific approaches to answer questions or concerns facing many of us in education.

According to McMillian (2016), educational research is a “systematic, disciplined inquiry applied to gathering, analyzing, and reporting information that addresses educational problems and questions. Systematic and disciplined means that there are accepted conventions, rules, and procedures for the way studies are conducted and standards for judging quality. The four boxes here provide a simplified version of the research process that you will define the research problems or objectives of your research. Next, you then develop a research plan and implement the plan. Finally, you interpret the results and report the findings.

Here’s a brief history of educational research.

During the late 1830s and early 1940s, at the beginning of common school (also known as public school), researchers found it important to collect data in a systematic way for school supervision and planning. Horace Mann and Henry Barnard are two of the pioneers to conduct systematic data collection and make the literature available to other educators and teachers so that they are aware of new ideas related to education.

In 1876, the funding of Johns Hopkins University as the first research university and other elite universities such as Stanford University and University of Chicago along with the first wave of land-grant public research universities heralded a new era in which more professors were expected to shift focus from teaching to conducting research. There was a belief that  social world could be “acted on and changed through scientific practices …and that teaching and the social welfare professions embodied scientific analysis and planning.” One of the most well-know scholars was John Dewey who established the Experimental Laboratory School at the University of Chicago. Dewey, a philosopher, was viewed as a leader in pedagogy with many ground-breaking theories. Dewey argued that education should be social and interactive. His research focused on how students could thrive in an environment where they could interact with curriculum and take control of their own learning. His education philosophy ran against other mainstream views of behaviorism, testing, and curriculum tracking.

After Dewey left University of Chicago for Teachers College at Columbia University, his successor Charles Judd, a psychologist, drastically changed the direction of educational research with a strong focus on scientific methods with quantitative data collection and analysis. His contemporary, Edward Thorndike, also a professor at Teachers College, published a book titled “An Introduction to Theory of Mental and Social Measurements” in which he advocated the use of statistics and precise measurements for data analysis. His positivist approach to educational research approach received wide acceptance in academia and became the dominant approach for decades to come.

During World War One, there was a need to use testing as an efficient way for military recruits. At the same time, there was a surge of populations and immigrants in the United States which led to increased enrollments in public schools. The focus of education reforms were in efficiency and social control. Testing and the study of racial and cultural differences in intelligence quotients were popular among education researchers.

After World War II, more universities were involved in education research and the findings were distributed through academic journals. Although positivist approach continued to be favored by many researchers, other theoretical frameworks such as constructivism, functionalism, and postmodernism were gaining tractions in academia. The emergence of various theoretical perspectives about knowledge and scientific methods have led to the rise of multiple research methods.

Further, the United States federal government has played a key role in providing funding for education research and the dissemination of evidence-based best practices. The government education funding agencies have a vested interest in supporting “applied research” over “basic or pure research” which was a drastic shift from scientific research on student learning and the curriculum to education programs that showed results.

Recent focus on “action research” as the new assessment ushered a new form of educational research that aims at improving educational practice of teachers to achieve student learning outcomes, not just to produce new knowledge.

From the brief introduction of educational research, we can see that the evolution was very much influenced by a number of historical and social factors. The approaches to educational research are pretty much shaped by various theoretical frameworks.

Currently, there are two main research paradigms: positivism and interpretivism. The positivist approach prefers quantitative methods which detach the researchers from the respondents. The preferred research methods include, but are not limited to, quantitative data such as statistical analysis, validated instruments for surveys, or structured interviews

The Interpretivism prefers qualitative methods which allow interaction between researchers and subjects. The preferred research methods include, but are not limited to, qualitative data such as personal documents, observation, or unstructured interviews.

Now let’s ask the question of why. Why do we learn to conduct educational research in this course? There are three quick reasons. First, we want to be an informed consumer of educational research. We need to be able to examine and evaluate claims made by researchers and have the knowledge to discern what methods they used to reach certain conclusions. Second, we need to know how to conduct our own research in our own settings in small-scale to seek understanding or answer of an issue. Conducting our own research is the first step to solve a problem. Third, we learn about educational research so we are informed of the best practices of of instructional strategies or policy implementation related to education. These skills will help use making important decisions about how we teach or work with students or teachers.

How do we conduct educational research? There are a wide variety of approaches. It usually starts with a research problem or issue that you would like to seek understanding, for example, how to enhance student engagement in the math classroom? Next, you will review literature to see if this question has been answered. Is there any gap in previous studies and current practices of new interventions. Based on the gap, you can formulate a hypothesis or research question. The following steps are to design your research by identifying sample populations, formulating steps to collect data, or implementing interventions to learn about the effect on subjects. Subsequently, we conduct data analysis and interpret the findings. Finally, we can conclude the study by presenting answers to research question, discussing research limitations, and exploring implications of this research.

We expect scientists to use the scientific approach to conduct research. It’s the same for education researchers. We conduct scientific inquiry to explain natural phenomena, to understand underlying relationships, and to use the information to predict and influence behavior. For example, we use scientific inquiry to explain why some teachers are more effective than others. This explanation could lead to a knowledge base for novice teachers to become effective teachers.

There are six principles of scientific inquiry:

1. Pose questions to be studied empirically: an empirical study is one that gathers evidence (data) that is based on observation, measurement, or experience that can be replicated by others.

2. Link research to relevant theory: A theory can be defined as a set of propositions that explain the relationship among observed phenomena. For example, Bloom’s taxonomy is well recognized and can be applied to students at any levels.

3. Use methods that permit direct investigation: We should always start with a research question and then match the best methods to answer the question.

4. Provide coherent, explicit, evidence-based reasoning: There should be a clear alignment between all aspects of research, from the research question, literature review to methods, findings, and conclusions.

5. Replicate and generalize: Findings from a study must be checked and validated and subsequent studies must determine whether results generalize to a broader population and to other contexts.

6. Subject findings to peer review: We share research findings through a peer-review process to increase the credibility of the findings.

Now let’s talk about different types of research.

First, quantitative research is more objective for the purpose of obtaining single truth. Its emphasis is on measurement and experiments.

Second, qualitative research relies on multiple realities, socially constructed meaning, verbal narratives and observation. The goal is to gain a deeper understanding of context, culture, and participant interactions with others to adequately study a phenomenon.

Third, mixed methods design is a combination of quantitative and qualitative methods.

We will explain more of each design in the following slides.

In the next two slides, we will provide a very high level overview of the three research methods.

In quantitative research, there are nonexperimental and experimental designs

In nonexperimental designs, a researcher has no direct control of any factors or phenomena, such as intervention or “treatment,” that may influence the participants’ performance. Nonexperimental studies can be classfied as correlational, causal comparative (also known as ex post facto), descriptive, and comparative.

First, correlational research looks at the relationship among two or more variables, for example, what is the relationship between creativity and aptitude? Or the relationship between physical education classes and engagement?

Second, causal comparative studies, or ex post facto studies, examine the interventions that occurred in the past and subsequent responses in such a way that may be possible to draw causal relationship between them. For example, how did the adoption of a new math curriculum affect student achievement? Another example is how do reading skills differ between 1st graders who attended preschool and those who did not?

Third, descriptive research includes studies that provide simple information about the frequency or amount of something, for example, how long teen students spend time on mobile phones?

Fourth, Comparative studies examine the differences between groups on a variable of interest, for example, do online students perform better or the same as face-to-face students?

In experimental designs, researchers control an intervention to investigate a causal relationship.

There are three types of experimental designs.

First in true experimental design, participants are randomly assigned to different groups.

Second in quasi-experimental design, participants are not randomly assigned.

Third in the single-subject design, only one or a few participants are studied.

There are a lot of information in this portion. We will look at each research design more carefully in the future modules.

There are six major qualitative research methods for various purposes. To put them in simple terms:

First, the purpose of Phenomenology is to understand the essence of a phenomenon.

Second, the purpose of Ethnography is to describe and understand a cultural group.

Third, the purpose of Grounded theory is to generate a theory.

Fourth, the purpose of Case studies is to study a single or a few programs in depth

Fifth, the purpose of Critical studies is to address issues of injustice and inequality.

Finally, the purpose of Narrative inquiries is to examine stories of individuals and groups for a deep understanding.

You will find more examples in the textbook.

Some research can combine both qualitative and quantitative methods, which allow one approach to strengthen the other.

The first one is explanatory sequential design in which quantitative methods are followed by the qualitative methods. For example, you would administer a survey first and then conduct interviews.

The second one is exploratory sequential design in which the qualitative methods are followed by the quantitative methods. For example, you would go into a school to observe common teaching practices with iPad and then administer a survey to see the common trends in utilizing iPad in the classroom.

The third one is convergent, also called triangulation design, in which both quantitative methods and qualitative methods are implemented more or less at the same time. For example, you would administer a survey and conduct interviews roughly at the same time period to save time. The researchers can then see if multiple sources of data can be triangulated to help explain the patterns of iPad uses in the classroom and why.
Now here’s a review of all educational research design we have mentioned so far. Take a moment to see if you understand the processes better.

We can also look at research from a different angle by thinking about the overall purposes.

The main purpose of basic research is to use the results for the development of theories. The goal of basic research is to understand and explain – to provide a broad understanding of a phenomenon.

The purpose of applied research is to use results to test theories and other ideas in the context of naturally occurring educational settings. It usually is focused on a problem that needs to be solved to improve the practice of education.

The purpose of action research is to solve a specific classroom or school problem or issue, improve practice, or help make a decision at a single local site. The intent is to improve practice immediately within one or a few classrooms or schools.

The purpose of evaluation research is to make decisions about the effectiveness or desirability of a program. The goal is to make judgements about alternatives in decision-making situations.
Now take a moment to enter in the text box, what kind of research methods might be more appropriate for the research problem/question that you have entered earlier.

Now, we have learned the various ways to conduct research. Let’s learn the format to present the research findings. Usually in a research manuscript, the paper starts with a title and author(s), a short abstract before the main introduction, followed by literature review, research problems or questions, research methods, research results, discussion, and conclusion. At the end of the paper, all references are provided.

Here’s a recap of this lecture. In this lecture we:

Discuss the importance of educational research

Learn a brief history of educational research

Describe the nature of scientific inquiry

Review the types of educational research, and

Identify research article format

I hope you have gained new insights of educational research.
